Situation1: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story:
I stared at the calendar on my phone, my thumb hovering over the event reminders. The national continuing education program for pharmacists was scheduled for this Sunday, the same day as our church’s annual service and community outreach. As a pharmacist, I knew how important it was to stay updated—my patients depended on my knowledge, and my license required these credits. Missing the program could set me back professionally, and I’d worked so hard to keep up with the latest treatments.

But as a Christian, I was expected to be present at church, especially for big events like this. My pastor had personally asked me to help organize the outreach, and I knew the congregation counted on my support. I could already imagine the disappointment in their faces if I didn’t show up. My heart felt heavy, torn between my commitment to my profession and my devotion to my faith community. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I found myself wrestling with guilt and anxiety, unsure which responsibility should come first.
